headline.main: Perseverance, Not Vindictiveness, In a Family Bereaved by Terrorism
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: COPING WITH A LOSS

lead_paragraph: At the heart of Dorothy Vauk's grief over the last-born of her nine children is a question that has haunted the nation since Sept. 11: How can someone ever manage to hate strangers? She asks it about the hijackers who plunged a jetliner into the Pentagon where her 37-year-old son, Ron, was the Navy's watch commander. Urgently trying to scramble jet fighters in defense of the capital, Lieutenant Commander Vauk perished in the first moments of what is now the nation's war against terrorism.
abstract: Dorothy Vauk of Nampa, Idaho, whose 37-year-old son, Ron, died in terrorist attack on Pentagon, expresses bewilderment that someone could hate strangers enough to kill them; she, like other surviving kin, sounds far more persevering than vindictive, farm more focused on wounded families than anonymous enemies; photo (M)
